name: Those Empty Eyes: A Chilling Novel of Suspense with a Shocking Twist

title: Fantastic
content: Love all Charlie Donlea’s books. I mostly listen on audible, long commute but some are not available so I’m reading those. Always catches me by surprise with the twist and turns and unexpected endings. I can’t wait for the next new one to come out. I Highly recommend this author !
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on September 15, 2024

title: Verified Purchase
content: This was a well written novel.  The writer had several story lines which come to a satisfying conclusion.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on September 30, 2024

title: page turner no doubt
content: So many different story lines kept coming while  tried to figure out who was who and how it would all come together.  Even a storyline based on recent news.  All the pain, revenge, and Alex non ending struggle to find out who killed her family and the caring of Garrett and Donna trying to protect an innocent child from the media and help her find her way.  The twists, I was at h the edge of the truth but backed off a couple of times, but was off on the second partner from childhood.  Great read with some solid information along the way.  Loved it!

title: Good moments, but overall mid.
content: That's the worst thing about this.  It's longer than it needs to be.  Twists and reveals are interesting, but too slow in occurring.  Information gets repeated a few times like we've likely forgotten it and some of it was easily overlooked, but I tried to read this as quickly as I could so those details hadn't escaped me.  Staying more focused on the central story rather than building up all the sidestories would have eliminated the need to repeat and retread elements of the story.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2024

title: Verified Purchase
content: The mid aspects of the story are its intent.  It does well as commentary for and against the true crime community and obsessive nature of media for stories like this.  The glorification, villainization and tokenization of victims based on the seeming whims of certain opinions or trends is fascinating to study, but not really the focus of this story.  I think, for that reason, it's actually a pretty neutral story and wants to just show both sides without firmly aligning with or against true crime enthusiasts.  Rather it wants all attention on the idea of justice with or without the courts.  The clearer commentary is on how some are able to skirt justice through wealth, power and/or influence.  I liked how the book handled that. A little vigilante action is always somewhat cathartic, but the buildup was longer and more involved than necessary.  Arguments can be made for and against all the elements that were woven in.  All the pieces did have a place and it all fit into the picture that the author wanted to present, but the puzzle would have been just as effective with 500 pieces as 1000.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on June 18, 2024
